title: Energy - dropping ball on stretched fabric

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students asked to use a graph to determine the spring constant <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of a spring. The spring is connected to a block of known mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> that rests on a surface where friction between the block and the surface is negligible. The students have the setup described, as well as a meterstick and a photogate which can measure the speed of the block at a specific position. The students do not have a scale or a force probe. (a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that can be graphed to determine <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. Include steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students asked to use a graph to determine the spring constant <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of a spring. The spring is connected to a block of known mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> that rests on a surface where friction between the block and the surface is negligible. The students have the setup described, as well as a meterstick and a photogate which can measure the speed of the block at a specific position. The students do not have a scale or a force probe. (a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that can be graphed to determine <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. Include steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the data collected in part (a) could be graphed, and how that graph would be analyzed to determine <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.

Another group of students uses the setup shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> to determine the acceleration due to gravity. They push a block of mass <math alttext="uppercase M equals 1.5 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mstyle></math> against a horizontal spring with spring constant <math alttext="k equals 20 newtons per meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N/m</mtext></mstyle></math>. Both the spring and block are on a table which is a height <math alttext="h equals 0.8 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>8</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math> above the floor. They push the block to the right, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>X</mi></mstyle></math> from equilibrium. The block is released from rest, follows the trajectory shown, and strikes the floor a horizontal distance <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>D</mi></mstyle></math> from the edge of the table. Air resistance and all frictional forces are negligible. The students record the initial displacement <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi>X</mi></math> of the block and the horizontal distance <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> traveled by the block before hitting the floor. The students repeat the experiment, changing <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>X</mi></mstyle></math> each time. The following table shows the data collected by the students. Horizontal Distance <math alttext="D in meters" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> Compression from Equilibrium <math alttext="0.31" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.31</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.20" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.20</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.46" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.46</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.30" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.30</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.58" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.58</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.40" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.40</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.73" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.73</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.50" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.50</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.85" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.85</mtext></math> <math alttext="0.60" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.60</mtext></math> The students correctly determine that the relationship between the compression of the spring <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>X</mi></mstyle></math> and the horizontal distance traveled by the block <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>D</mi></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="D equals, X times the square root of the fraction with numerator 2 k h and denominator lowercase m g" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mi>D</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>X</mi> <msqrt> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mi>k</mi> <mi>h</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>M</mi> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </msqrt> </mstyle> </math>. The students create a graph with <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> plotted on the vertical axis. (c) i. Indicate which measured or calculated quantity could be plotted on the horizontal axis to yield a linear graph whose slope can be used to calculate an experimental value for the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>g</mi></mstyle></math>. You may use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities (including units) that are not already in the table. Vertical: _____<math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>D</mi></mstyle></math>_____ Horizontal: _____ _____

ii. On the grid shown in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) that can be used to determine <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>g</mi></mstyle></math>. Scale the graph as appropriate. Clearly label the horizontal axis, including units.
iii. Draw a best–fit line for the data.

(d) Calculate an experimental value for the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>g</mi></mstyle></math> using the best–fit line that you drew in part (c)(iii).

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
